content: Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, People ¡¯s Republic of China*SSupporting InformationABSTRACT: By condensing a trisamino linker with one of the two analogous bisaldehydeligands, pills and tetrahedrons could be self-assembled. The self-assembled preference couldbe controlled by tuning the reaction conditions, including the size of side chain,concentration, and temperature. Coordination of silver cation quenches the ?uorescence ofthe?uorene moieties on the pill, opening up opportunities for Ag+cation detection.

Ligand 1bbearing butyl side chains is signi ?cantlymore soluble in CDCl 3.W e ?rst combined 1a(0.27 mg, 1mM) and tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TREN) (0.07 mg, 0.83mM) in CDCl3(0.6 mL). The TREN/ 1aratio is slightlyhigher than 2:3, to guarantee the full conversion of thealdehyde precursor, given that the error often occurs inweighing a small amount of substances. The mixture solutionwas kept at 25 ¡ãC for 12 h, and its1H NMR spectrum wasrecorded (see Figure 2 A). A set of relatively sharp resonanceswere observed in the1H NMR spectrum, indicating that a pill-shaped capsule 2awith relatively high symmetry was producedas the predominant product. The1H NMR yield of 2awascalculated to be 82%, by using ethyl acetate as an internalstandard in the NMR sample. The1H NMR spectrum ( Figure2A) of 2adi?ers from that of the precursor 1a. Experimental detailsGeneral InformationAll reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Manipulations were performed under a normal laboratory atmosphere unless otherwise noted. The compounds S1,1 S22 and S33were prepared according to literature. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded at ambient temperature using Bruker AVANCE III 400/500 or Agilent DD2 600 spectrometers, with working frequencies of 400/500/600 and 100/125/150 MHz for 1H and 13C, respectively. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to the residual internal non-deuterated solvent signals (CDCl 3: ¦Ä =7.26 ppm, CDCl 3/CD 3OD: ¦Ä = 3.33 ppm). High-resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were measured using a SHIMADZU liquid chromatograph mass spectrometry ion trap time of flight (LCMS-IT-TOF) instrument, or a MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany). PL spectra were recorded on a RF-5301 fluorescence spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Corporation, Japan) at 298 K. X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer. 42. Synthetic procedures and compound characterizationScheme S1. Synthesis of 1a1a: Compound S1 (200 mg) and compound S2 (184.6 mg) were dissolved in Et 3N (30 mL) under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen. Pd(PPh 3)4 (32 mg) and CuI (10.8 mg) were then added and the reaction mixture was stirred at 100 oC for 2d. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, yielding crude product. The crude product was further purified by column chromatography (PE/DCM = 1:1, v/v) to give 1a as a light yellow solid (90 mg). 1a was fully characterized by 1H (Figure S1) and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Figure S2) and mass spectrometry (Figure S3), as well as 2D NMR spectroscopy (Figure S4,S5). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä 10.04 (s, 2H), 7.89 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 4H), 7.74 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 2H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 4H), 7.65 (d, J = 1.3 Hz, 2H), 7.57 (dd, J = 7.9, 1.5 Hz, 2H), 1.54 (s, 6H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä 191.4, 154.1, 139.2, 135.4, 132.1, 131.2, 129.6, 126.2, 121.6, 120.5, 94.2, 89.1, 47.0, 26.9. Synthesis of 1b1b: Compound S3 (200 mg) and compound S2 (149 mg) were dissolved in Et 3N (30 mL) under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen. Pd(PPh 3)4 (26 mg) and CuI (8.7 mg) were then added and the reaction mixture was stirred at 100 oC for 2d. After cooling to room temperature, the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, yielding the crude product. The crude product was further purified by column chromatography (PE/DCM = 1:1, v/v) to give 1b as a light yellow solid (100 mg). 1b was fully characterized by 1H (Figure S6) and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Figure S7) and mass spectrometry (Figure S8), as well as 2D NMR spectroscopy (Figure S9,S10). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä 10.04 (s, 2H), 7.90 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 4H), 7.72 (dd, J = 8.1, 1.4 Hz, 6H), 7.59 ¨C 7.53 (m, 4H), 2.03 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 4H), 1.11 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 4H), 0.70 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 6H), 0.60 (s, 4H).

Key correlation peaks between protons a and b, as well as d and e are labeled.11Figure S10 Partial 1H-1H NOESY spectrum (500 MHz, CDCl 3, 298K) of 1b. A key correlation peak between protons f and b are labeled.12The pill namely 2a was obtained by condensing 1a (1.6 mg, 6 mM) and tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TREN) (0.42 mg, 5 mM) in CDCl 3 (0.6 mL). The solution was sealed in a NMR tube without stirring for 12h to let the system to reach the equilibrium. The formation of 2a was characterized by both NMR spectroscopy (Figure S11,S12,S13,S14), mass spectrometry (Figure S15) and single crystallography (see Figure 3A in the main text). Specifically, the 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S11) proved the presence of CH¡¤¡¤¡¤? interaction, i.e., see the discussion in the main text. The peak assignment was made based on two-dimensional NMR spectra, including COSY (Figure S13) and NOESY (Figure S14). 1H NMR diffusion-ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) experiments (Figure S16) demonstrate that 2a was produced as a relatively pure compound.

1H NMR diffusion-ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) experiments (Figure S21) demonstrate that 3b has a smaller diffusion coefficient than that of 2b in CDCl 3, indicating that the former compound is composed of more building blocks than the latter one.23Pure tetrahedral cage 3b could be obtained by means of crystallization. Condensing 1b (1.28mg, 4mM) and tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TREN) (0.291mg, 3.33 mM) in CDCl 3 (0.6 mL), at 0 oC, produced a mixture containing a pill 2b (20%) and a tetrahedron 3b (71%), determined by using ethyl acetate as an internal standard in the NMR sample. Slow evaporation of the solvent at 0 oC yielded a number of crystalline materials, which was re-dissolved in CDCl 3 and its 1H NMR spectrum was recorded, indicating that the crystalline materials correspond to pure 3b. The structure of 3b was supported by both 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Figure S22, S23). The peak assignment was made based on two-dimensional NMR spectra, including COSY (Figure S24) and NOESY (Figure S25). 1H NMR diffusion-ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) experiments (Figure S26) demonstrate that 3b is a pure compound.24Figure S22 1H NMR spectrum (400 MHz, CDCl 3, 298 K) of 3b.25Figure S23 13C NMR spectrum (125 MHz, CDCl 3, 298 K) of 3b.26Figure S24 1H-1H COSY spectrum (500 MHz, CDCl 3, 298 K) of 3b. Key correlation peaks protons a and b, as well as c and d are labeled.27Figure S25 1H-1H NOESY spectrum (500 MHz, CDCl 3, 298 K) of 3b. Key correlation peaks protons f and b, as well as e and g are labeled.

Figure S26 The DOSY spectrum of 3b (500 MHz, CDCl 3, 298 K).28A solution of AgBF 4 (15.9 mM) in CD 3OD (62.7 ¦ÌL) was added into the solution (CDCl 3 / 0.6 mL ) of the self-assemled products combining 1b (2 mM) and TREN (1.67 mM) containing both 2b and 3b, which resulted in a remarkable change in the 1H NMR spectrum(see Figure 2E in the main text). This observation indicates the formation of pill-shaped self-assembly product, namely, 2b?2Ag+. The peak assignment was made based on two-dimensional NMR spectra, including COSY (Figure S27) and NOESY (Figure S28). 1H NMR diffusion-ordered spectroscopy (DOSY) experiments (Figure S29) demonstrate that 2b?2Ag+ is a pure compound.
Controllable Self-Assembly of Pills and Cages via ImineCondensation for Silver Cation DetectionNing Cao, Yan Wang, Xujun Zheng, Tianyu Jiao, and Hao Li *

28,29This could be accomplished bysophisticatedly designing the self-assembly precursors orcontrolling the reaction conditions. Therefore, it would be ofimportance to unravel the relationship between the self-assembly preference and the reaction factors, such asgeometries of the building blocks,30solvent,31reactiontemperature,32,33concentration,34usage of guest template,34etc. Herein, we demonstrate ( Figure 1 ) that condensation ofone of the two pseudo-linear bisaldehyde ligands bearing a?uorene group and a trisamino linkage leads to the formationof a mixture of a pill-shaped and a tetrahedral cage, which areself-assembled in the manner of [2 + 3] and [4 + 6],respectively. The self-assembly pathway could be in ?uenced byboth intrinsic and extrinsic reaction e ?ects, including (i) morebulky side chains on the bisaldehydes favor the formation oftetrahedral product; (ii) higher precursor concentration favorsthe tetrahedrons; (iii) higher reaction temperature favors themolecular pills; and (iv) addition of metal cations shifts theequilibrium to the side of the pills almost exclusively.

When 1b(0.32 mg, 1 mM) was combined with tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TREN) (0.07 mg, 0.83 mM) in CDCl3(0.6 mL) at 25 ¡ãC, two sets of resonances were observed in the1H NMR spectrum ( Figure 2 B). This observation indicatesthat two major products were obtained, including a pill 2banda tetrahedron 3b, which were self-assembled in the manner of[2 + 3] and [4 + 6], respectively. Pill 2bis an analogue of 2a,which also has a characteristic upshifted proton resonance dueto the CH ?¦Ðinteractions. The yields of 2band3bare 46%and 33%, respectively, determined by using an internalstandard. The peaks corresponding to both 2band 3bareobserved in the mass spectra (see Figures S19 and S20 in theSupporting Information).

The self-assembly occurred at the following temperatures, including (a) 0 oC, (b) 25 oC, (c) 35 oC, and (d) 55 oC. The concentrations of 1b and TREN are 4 and 3.33 mM, respectively.36We also investigated the impact of temperature on the self-assembly preference. We performed condensation of 1b and TREN in CDCl 3 at variable temperatures, namely 0 oC, 25 oC, 35 oC, and 55 oC. The concentration of 1b is 4 mM. By using a similar method, in the condition of 0 oC, 25 oC, 35 oC, and 55 oC, the yields of 2b were calculated to be 20%, 21%, 28%, and 31%; the yields of 3b were calculated to be 71%, 51%, 43%, and 17%.
